concepts.concept_name: Definition of matter and its physical nature
Latent heat and specific latent heat
Effect of pressure and temperature on states

in_scope: Matter: anything with mass and volume
Kinetic particle theory revision
Interconversion: melting, boiling, freezing, condensation, sublimation
Latent heat of fusion and vaporization
Specific latent heat calculations
Effect of pressure on boiling point and melting point
Effect of temperature on particle motion
Diffusion in gases and liquids
Brownian motion as evidence of kinetic theory
out_of_scope: Basic states of matter — Covered in Class 8
Plasma state — Introduced in Class 10
Gas laws in detail — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Review of Bohr's atomic model and limitations
Electron shells and electronic configuration up to 30

in_scope: Bohr model: electrons in fixed orbits (K, L, M, N)
Maximum electrons per shell: 2n²
Electronic configuration of elements 1-30
Valence electrons and valency
Octet rule: atoms tend to have 8 electrons in outer shell
Duplet rule: for hydrogen and helium
Ionic bond: transfer of electrons, metal + non-metal
Covalent bond: sharing of electrons, non-metal + non-metal
Single, double, and triple covalent bonds
Electrovalency: number of electrons transferred
Covalency: number of electrons shared
Properties of ionic and covalent compounds
out_of_scope: Basic atomic structure — Covered in Class 8
Quantum numbers and orbitals — Introduced in Class 10
Coordinate and metallic bonding — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Modern periodic law and long form periodic table
Groups and periods: structure and significance
Classification of elements: s, p, d, f blocks
Periodic trends: atomic size, ionization energy, electronegativity

in_scope: Dobereiner's triads and limitations
Newlands' law of octaves and limitations
Mendeleev's periodic law: based on atomic mass
Mendeleev's achievements and limitations
Modern periodic law: based on atomic number
Long form periodic table: 7 periods, 18 groups
Groups: vertical columns, same valence electrons
Periods: horizontal rows, same number of shells
s-block, p-block, d-block, f-block elements
Atomic radius decreases across period, increases down group
Ionization energy increases across period, decreases down group
Electronegativity trends
Metallic character decreases across period, increases down group
out_of_scope: Basic element classification — Covered in Class 8
Detailed d-block and f-block chemistry — Introduced in Class 10
Electron affinity calculations — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Law of conservation of mass in equations
Types of chemical reactions: synthesis, decomposition, displacement

in_scope: Writing word equations for reactions
Converting word equations to symbol equations
Reactants and products
Law of conservation of mass: atoms are neither created nor destroyed
Balancing equations by trial and error method
Balancing equations systematically
Coefficients vs subscripts
Combination/synthesis reactions: A + B → AB
Decomposition reactions: AB → A + B
Single displacement: A + BC → AC + B
Double displacement: AB + CD → AD + CB
Reading equations in terms of atoms, molecules, moles
out_of_scope: Basic equation writing — Covered in Class 8
Redox equation balancing — Introduced in Class 10
Half-reaction method — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Relative atomic mass and molecular mass
Avogadro's number and the mole concept
Molar mass and gram atomic mass

in_scope: Atomic mass unit (amu or u)
Relative atomic mass: compared to C-12
Relative molecular mass: sum of atomic masses
Avogadro's number: 6.022 × 10²³
Mole: amount containing Avogadro's number of particles
Molar mass: mass of one mole in grams
Gram atomic mass and gram molecular mass
Mole = mass/molar mass
Number of particles = moles × Avogadro's number
Percentage composition from formula
Empirical formula: simplest whole number ratio
Molecular formula = n × empirical formula
out_of_scope: Basic formula calculations — Covered in Class 8
Stoichiometry with limiting reagent — Introduced in Class 10
Molar volume of gases — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Strong and weak acids and bases
Types of salts and their properties

in_scope: Arrhenius: acids produce H⁺, bases produce OH⁻
Bronsted-Lowry: acids are proton donors, bases are proton acceptors
Properties of acids: sour taste, turn blue litmus red, react with metals
Properties of bases: bitter taste, soapy feel, turn red litmus blue
pH scale: 0-14, pH 7 is neutral
pH < 7 acidic, pH > 7 basic
Indicators: litmus, methyl orange, phenolphthalein
Strong acids: HCl, HNO₃, H₂SO₄ (complete dissociation)
Weak acids: CH₃COOH, H₂CO₃ (partial dissociation)
Strong bases: NaOH, KOH; Weak bases: NH₄OH
Neutralization: acid + base → salt + water
Normal salts, acidic salts, basic salts
out_of_scope: Basic acid-base concept — Covered in Class 8
Lewis acid-base theory — Introduced in Class 10
Buffer solutions — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Position of hydrogen in periodic table
Laboratory and industrial preparation of hydrogen
Physical and chemical properties of hydrogen
Uses of hydrogen and hydrogen fuel

in_scope: Hydrogen: unique position (can be placed in Group 1 or 17)
Similarities with alkali metals and halogens
Isotopes: protium (H), deuterium (D), tritium (T)
Lab preparation: Zn + dil. H₂SO₄ → ZnSO₄ + H₂↑
Collection by downward displacement of water
Industrial: electrolysis of water, steam reforming
Physical: colorless, odorless, lightest gas, slightly soluble
Chemical: combustion, reaction with metals and non-metals
Reduction of metal oxides (CuO + H₂ → Cu + H₂O)
Burning splint test: pop sound
Uses: fuel cells, Haber process, hydrogenation
Hydrogen as a reducing agent
out_of_scope: Basic hydrogen properties — Covered in Class 8
Hydrogen bonding in detail — Introduced in Class 10
Industrial processes in detail — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Structure and properties of water molecule
Water as a solvent and solutions
Chemical properties and reactions of water
Hardness of water and water softening

in_scope: Water molecule: H₂O, bent shape, polar molecule
Hydrogen bonding between water molecules
Maximum density at 4°C
Anomalous expansion: expands on freezing
Importance of anomalous behavior for aquatic life
Water as universal solvent
Concentration terms: molarity, percentage
Chemical reactions: with metals, non-metals, oxides
Synthesis and decomposition of water
Hard water: temporary (Ca(HCO₃)₂) and permanent (CaSO₄)
Softening: boiling, Clark's method, ion exchange
out_of_scope: Basic water properties — Covered in Class 8
Colligative properties — Introduced in Class 10
Detailed water treatment — Introduced in Class 10

in_scope: Composition: N₂ (78%), O₂ (21%), Ar (0.93%), CO₂ (0.04%)
Primary pollutants: CO, SO₂, NOₓ, particulates
Secondary pollutants: ozone, smog
Sources: vehicles, industries, power plants
Greenhouse gases: CO₂, CH₄, N₂O, CFCs
Greenhouse effect mechanism
Global warming: causes and effects
Ozone (O₃) in stratosphere: UV protection
CFCs and ozone depletion
Acid rain: SO₂ + H₂O → H₂SO₃, NO₂ + H₂O → HNO₃
Effects of acid rain on environment
Control measures: catalytic converters, scrubbers
out_of_scope: Basic pollution concepts — Covered in Class 8
Detailed environmental chemistry — Introduced in Class 10
Industrial pollution control — Introduced in Class 10

in_scope: Laboratory safety rules and precautions
Common laboratory apparatus and their uses
Bunsen burner: parts and types of flames
Measuring volume: pipette, burette, measuring cylinder
Heating techniques and precautions
Preparation of gases: H₂, O₂, CO₂, NH₃, Cl₂
Collection methods: downward displacement, upward delivery
Tests for gases: H₂ (pop), O₂ (glowing splint), CO₂ (lime water)
Tests for ions: flame tests, precipitation tests
Crystallization and recrystallization
Filtration and evaporation techniques
out_of_scope: Basic lab skills — Covered in Class 8
Titration techniques — Introduced in Class 10
Qualitative analysis — Introduced in Class 10

name: Study of Compounds: Ammonia and Nitric Acid

concepts.concept_name: Physical and chemical properties of ammonia

in_scope: Ammonia (NH₃) preparation: NH₄Cl + Ca(OH)₂ → CaCl₂ + H₂O + 2NH₃
Collection by downward displacement of air (lighter than air)
Physical: colorless, pungent smell, lighter than air, very soluble
Chemical: basic gas, forms NH₄OH in water, reacts with acids
Reaction with HCl: dense white fumes of NH₄Cl
Fountain experiment
Industrial preparation: Haber process (N₂ + 3H₂ ⇌ 2NH₃)
Uses: fertilizers, explosives, cleaning agents
Nitric acid preparation: Ostwald process
Lab preparation from nitrates
Properties of nitric acid: oxidizing agent, brown fumes
Uses of nitric acid
out_of_scope: Basic nitrogen compounds — Covered in Class 8
Detailed Haber process — Introduced in Class 10
Industrial processes in detail — Introduced in Class 10

name: Study of Compounds: Hydrochloric Acid and Sulphuric Acid

concepts.concept_name: Preparation and properties of hydrochloric acid
Reactions and uses of hydrochloric acid
Preparation and properties of sulphuric acid
Dilution of sulphuric acid and uses

in_scope: HCl preparation: NaCl + H₂SO₄ → NaHSO₄ + HCl
Properties of HCl: acidic, reacts with metals, bases, carbonates
Tests with AgNO₃: white precipitate of AgCl
Uses of HCl: pickling, manufacture of chlorides
H₂SO₄ manufacture: Contact process
Concentrated H₂SO₄: dehydrating and oxidizing agent
Dilute H₂SO₄: typical acid reactions
Reaction with metals: Zn + H₂SO₄ → ZnSO₄ + H₂
Reaction with bases and carbonates
Dilution: add acid to water, never water to acid
Uses: batteries, fertilizers, manufacturing
out_of_scope: Basic acid properties — Covered in Class 8
Contact process in detail — Introduced in Class 10
Industrial processes — Introduced in Class 10
